body.p: Revd
Editor of the Occident

The interesting thing about this
letter which comes from a pious soul
though a befuddled mind, is the naivite
with which orthodox Jews regarded
reformers. This man thought that
they were aching for a change, any
change
Buffalo, Sunday, 14 Sivan, 5609 [June 1849]
To the accomplished etc. etc

I heard from indirect sources, and also have read in the
Occident, that scholars and rabbis living here in America, and
who sit on the seat of instruction to teach the children of Israel the
way to go and the thing to do, will soon gather in assembly.
Although I have not attained to the destruction of being one of the
delegates, for I am a stranger here, a guest who seeks no more
than lodgings, and cannot compare with you; nevertheless,
I cannot refrain, and shut my mouth. I want to know why
and wherefore. In this great cry I, the youngest among the
families of Israel, agree with the learned Mr. S. Abraham
with regard to everything he pointed out in the Occident of
last month. Your Honor knows that to the customs of our
fathers one may not add, nor detract from them. Then again,
my soul wants to know how it is possible to imagine
changing the prayers now established; to distort the
established rules of Ezra the Scribe [his memory for a
blessing], with whom were many prophets, and whose
actions were undertaken at God's command and insperation.
How can we, therefore, consider the reduction of the number
called up to the Torah on every holy Sabbath from the
number severe and one ?. They may be wise, but
they do not know how to do good. All they can do is to come
together and place a yoke and a burden upon us. They
have a sword in their hand to cut down the tree of the
knowledge of good, and to change the traditions of our

sages [their memory for a blessing] and prophets
[their soul rest in the bag of life]. I therefore come with
a plea and request to your Great Honor not to
obey the priest who comes to perform the service of
the high priest in the holy place, and like a poor
man on Passover who begs for a piece of bread to
support his breaking heart, thus changing the order of
of purity and holiness, to pray in a strange language,
and perverted speech. What is this strange service
which we, the congregation of Israel, the witnesses of
Sinai, the descendants of Abraham, must never, never
God forbid, do this?

My hand is still stretched out, and my quick pen
continues to speak, to be a good pleader and intercessor,
to speak righteousness for those who are about to
meet in the shadow of fine perfume. Who is the first
who began to change our holy language for a foreign one? And
seeking one's people's good, for the remnant of Israel who do
no evil, (one understands that) the scattered grapes of Ephraim
are better than the entire crop of Yahuda*. Outside of the lang?
is there no wisdom in it. Ah, to teach these goyim we have
numerous commentaries on the Torah and the commandments, so
what more do we have to call out to God, the Lord of Hosts,
the God of Israel. We have six volumes of Gemara,
and ethical books, and legal works of the elder and younger
legalists—wealth of mind. We have no portion or inheritance

to go in foreign ways, contrary to our holy Law. My
heart, my heart! How great is my pain, and my
eyes shed tears because of the breach of my people
